title: The Little LISPer : Daniel P. Friedman : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
@nyrath

Ah, LISP. Used to work with a couple of LISP zealots back in those days. They sang from the same hymnbook, could have written that article.

We all had well-thumbed copies of The Little LISPer on our desks. (Fantastic, insightful, and very brief text, BTW. Recommended.)

The issues that killed LISP for us were the same: It was incredibly efficient and robust for exactly two people, and a major PITA for everyone else. Plus, the flavor we were mandated to use couldn't handle large 2D or 3D arrays, so we unenlightened ones had to write procedures in C and assembler to help LISP out, to the chagrin of the LISPers.

After several months of delays, drama, and excuses, plus, to be fair, a few absolutely brilliant moments, management pulled the plug. We switched to all C and were able to finish the project in a single but far more mundane and productive month.

https://archive.org/details/tlLISP

title: Unicode operators for semantically correct programming

last_post.content:
🆕 blog! “Unicode operators for semantically correct programming”

Why do most programming languages use the / character when we have a perfectly good ÷ symbol? Similarly, why use != instead of ≠? Or => rather than →? The obvious answer is that the humble keyboard usually only has around 100 keys - and most humans have a hard time remembering where tho…

👀 Read more: https://shkspr.mobi/blog/2023/01/unicode-operators-for-semantically-correct-programming/

title: Infinite partial sumsets in the primes

last_post.content: Tamar Ziegler and I have just uploaded a short #NumberTheory paper to the #arXiv titled "infinite partial sumsets in the primes". https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10303 The main result is that there exist two increasing sequences \(a_1 < a_2 < \dots \) and \(b_1 < b_2 < \dots\) such that \(a_i+b_j\) is prime for all \(i<j\). The argument uses the Maynard sieve and an intersectivity lemma of Bergelson. I discuss this result further on my blog at https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2023/01/26/infinite-partial-sumsets-in-the-primes/\)

It just struck me that container queries are amazing for typesetting on the web. You could easily do something like...

```css
.container { container-type: inline-size; }

p {
font-size: clamp(1rem, 2.5cqw, 2rem);
line-height: clamp(1.35rem, 3.5cqw, 1.9rem);
}

```

...and have your text change size depending on the measure and the size of the container. No more hacks! https://www.robinrendle.com/notes/container-queries-and-typography/

Venture capital-backed startups used to IPO but now they're being acquired.

My new paper with B. Pellegrino documents this secular shift and shows that serial acquirers of startups have become particularly insulated from product market competition.

We further show that these trends are accompanied by an increase in the opportunity cost of going public.

These facts are consistent with the hypothesis that startup acquisitions have contributed to rising oligopoly power.

https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4322834
